turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: David?

turns.speaker: DAVID GOTTSCHALK
turns.text: Who's there?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Everyone. Working overtime. Just for you.

turns.speaker: DAVID GOTTSCHALK
turns.text: Did you speak to Farlow?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yes. We're suing.

turns.speaker: DAVID GOTTSCHALK
turns.text: Is that absolutely necessary? It'll just make it a bigger story.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: David, he signed an agreement that he wouldn't talk to the press and he's libeled me by saying I faked the figures. You're not going soft on me, are you?

turns.speaker: DAVID GOTTSCHALK
turns.text: Well, I suppose we could use another good public feud...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Exactly...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, come on! This is such bullshit! The work is getting done, David. Lucky keeps me on top of everything.

turns.speaker: DAVID GOTTSCHALK
turns.text: Lucy isn't you. We're losing something without you being here. Now, I know this is a rough time for you, but I think we should make another arrangement.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: What the hell does that mean? How much more do I have to do to prove how important this magazine is to me?

turns.speaker: DAVID GOTTSCHALK
turns.text: If this magazine is so important to you Annie, why are you in Montana?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Uh, yes... Sure, David.

turns.speaker: DAVID GOTTSCHALK
turns.text: All right. Speak to you then.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: It's me.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: So, what, uh, what train are you taking?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I should be in by two.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Okay. You want me to pick you up?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Sure... What's Grace up to?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Riding with Judith.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I'm sorry about last night. I shouldn't have brought it up over the phone.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: That's okay. We have to talk about it and we're not always in the same place ... so... I just have to get used to it.  What do you want to do about dinner?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I don't know. We'll figure it out.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Okay. We'll see you later then.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah. Bye.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: What about Grace?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: She was in pretty bad shape. They've done a C.A.T. Scan -- she has some hemorrhaging...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: That bag's almost empty.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: No, it's got a little left. They'll be in to change it.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Robert, you leave it up these people...!

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Tch. What are you --

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: What did he say?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Nothing new. He's just going off duty.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I should go get some of her things.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: No, let me go.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: No, I'll go. You stay... In case she wakes up.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I saw Judith's parents while you were at the apartment...  I wanted to say something...  But I... I was so relieved that Grace was still... that it wasn't our daughter.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: We're very lucky.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: The funeral's on Friday.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Oh, uh, I meant to tell you... Alex brought that fabric over...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: It's on the table by the phone. I didn't know what to tell him...  ... Whether or not we were...  ... if we still we're thinking of redoing the couch.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: ... And uh... Mario called about moving the wisteria?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh. Right. I'll call him.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: "... FRESH, WIND IN HER HAIR... LIFE WITHOUT CARE... SHE'S BROKE... BUT IT'S 'OK'...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Sing it to me, Frankie!

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: How's my pregnant chick!

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You can hardly get your arms around me. How depressing. You're so early.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I had to excuse myself from a meeting. It's ridiculous. I kept thinking about the baby... you... and, I swear, I was going to start bawling right into my briefs.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Aw... that's so sweet.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I love you.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Do you? Do you really?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You've got to stop doing that?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Doing what?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Helping all the time! Running to her every time she trips or falls... Anticipating her all the time.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: How was the dinner?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: All our "favorite" people were there saying all their "favorite" things about their "favorite" subjects. I thought to myself, we've been friends with these people almost twenty years and nobody knows anybody. We're so afraid we won't like each other and have nobody go to dinners with.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Why did you go?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: They're still our friends, Annie. It's nothing serious. You kid about them all the time... And I could tell Paul really appreciated me being there.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Did you get a hold of that horse guy?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: What did he say?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: What was I saying?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: About us going someplace warm... Someplace Grace'll have to wear shorts or bathing suits or summer dresses...

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I don't understand. You just said he said no.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: He did, but... I think I can change his mind.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: That's the craziest thing I ever heard. Absolutely not.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Robert, Grace isn't adjusting to school. And she can't sit in this apartment all day... I think it would be good for her.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: NO! What are you -- you're serious about this?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I've called Liz. They can set me up with a trailer for Pilgrim. I thought we'd stay at motels along the way...

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: You've already made arrangements!?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: No. I was just researching. Calm down.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I come home and you tell me we're going to drive a psychotic horse to Montana! I can't just pick up and leave...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I'm not asking you to. I'll do it.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: You want to do this by yourself? How? You can't take care of Pilgrim all the --

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: He'll be sedated. I know horses, Robert. I'm the one who taught Grace how to ride.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: What... Bo-... What about the magazine?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I'm in charge. I went back very soon after the accident. They didn't expect me for a couple of months. I'll just take that time now... I can still oversee things from Montana... Take my fax... My computer...

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: No. It's, uh... No, I really don't think it's a good idea

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Why?!

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Her psychiatrist... said... she needs security now... stability...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I can't say he's been all that effective with her.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Are you a psychiatrist? He said it takes time.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I don't care what he says! We have to do something, Robert! I can't sit here and trust everything's going to work out just by pretending it will.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I'm not pretending anything!

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I really wish I could understand why you think this is so necessary.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Robert, we're losing her. We're losing her.  I don't care what the doctors say. The truth is, they don't know anymore than we do -- less, when it comes to Grace... This may not sound sensible or... logical, but nobody's suggesting anything better. I can't explain it, Robert. I just have this feeling... this annoying... bloody feeling that if... if, somehow, Pilgrim can be made all right... then so can Grace. I just know it!

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: What if she doesn't want to go?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: She will if you think she should.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: And you think it's best if I don't come.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: No, that's not what I said. I'm not a dictator. If you feel you should come, then come. Just do whatever you think is right.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah. She seems to be getting more comfortable on the ranch, which is why I said yes to this move. But, whenever it's just the two of us, I don't know... Anyway... what's happening with the Delco lawsuit?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Taking forever. I just got an additional list of sixty-two employees to interview before Monday. I don't know how I'm going to do it.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well, it's good that you're there.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: So, how are you doing in Marlboro country? Is the magazine complaining at all?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah, but nothing I can't handle. Lucy tells me she thinks Gottchalks's plotting, but what else is new.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: When are you coming home?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You know, I just asked that myself tonight. He doesn't know.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Well then... maybe I will take some time... come visit.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I miss you, Annie.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I know. We miss you too.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Good night.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Night.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I thought you guys were going to call me.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, Robert, I'm sorry. We were so tired from the branding. Grace barely made it to her bed and I didn't have the energy to take my clothes off.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Oh well... branding will do that to you.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Everything all right.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Huh-huh. You?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Fine. Actually, today was a good day. You should have seen her.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I wish I did.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Well, uh the real reason I called, actually, was to tell you I saw Lucy at Jo-Jo's tonight and she seems very worried.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: About what?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Apparently, Gottschalk's been seen around town lunching with some very prominent magazine editors. Lucy said she tried to call you, but no one answered so she faxed you the list of names. She said one of them have contracts up fairly soon.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh. I didn't look at my faxes today. We left before sunrise.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Honey, I hope you're not endangering your position. Listen, if you need to come back and you want me to come take over, for a while, I'll work it out. I mean, the firm's got other lawyers, but the magazine's got only one of you.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Small bed. Maybe I should sleep in the barn.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You're allergic to hay.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I apologize for the surprise, but the days only opened yesterday and I figured...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You don't have to explain. You have every right to come.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I can see why you put your faith in him. He's a genuine... good guy... Good at what he does. That's rare.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: You were right about coming here. I'm sorry for not thinking...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: No, it's okay. Believe me, there were plenty of times I didn't know what the hell was right.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: How are you feeling about work?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Let's not talk about that now.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Are you going to stay in the city or go up to Connecticut?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Connecticut. I told the office I'd work out of there next week. When are you planning to start back?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Probably first thing in the morning. It's too late to start now. I'm going to try not to do too much driving in the dark.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: May I have a suggestion?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah, what?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Take your time.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I'll tell you something, Annie -- I stood there looking at what was happening to that horse... And, I swear, it felt like the same thing was happening to me.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I don't understa-

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: And I have two choices. I can either fight the way things are, or accept them.  See, I always knew I loved you more. Didn't bother me. I always felt lucky... a little amazed... that such a vibrant, beautiful woman would want to be with a man like me... And I guess I thought as long as I did everything right -- if I was the best husband I could be, the best father... even being a good lawyer only mattered to me because of what it meant for us... if I could do all that, it wouldn't make any difference if we loved each other the same or not... I wasn't asking for more. I told myself I didn't need more.  But you don't know how you feel about me. You don't know... if you want a life with me anymore...  And I don't want you to come home until you do know...  ... one way or the other.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Hi. Um, there doesn't seem to be any hotel room available and someone told me to come here and ask for "Tubab" who might to have a place for me to stay. Are you "Tubab"?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: No. I am a "tubab."

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Tubab means white man.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: Was the trip okay?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Mmm. I made good time.  Pilgrim's in the back. I found a new stable, but they can't take him until tomorrow.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I have so much to tell you.

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: You want to take a walk with me?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Where to?

turns.speaker: ROBERT
turns.text: I don't know. Let's just go and... we'll see...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You know, that's interesting. I always wondered when I went into a restaurant what was the difference between a regular steak or a Black Angus steak. I couldn't taste any difference although I could swear one was more tender. I didn't know there was that big a difference between cows...  I've never been on a cow farm before. I must say, the bulls seem to have the best time of it. Just laying around the fields all day until they're asked to...  do their... work.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Well, get born a bull, got a ninety percent chance of getting castrated and served up as hamburger. On a balance I reckon I'd choose being a cow.  Would you mind passing that salad young lady?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Nobody's using it. Silly for her to be driving back and forth when she don't know her way around that well...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, I don't know...

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Well, I know Peterson's. Old place is as good as falling down around your ears.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well, did you ever think about hiring a business manager?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: We have a business manager. The best around.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I'll have another round of that spaghetti if may?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Absolutely. I made enough for an army.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: It's so cruel.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: No. He had the choice.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: What choice!!?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Either fight the way things are or accept it.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: There's coffee inside... I was just bringing this to Tom.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Would you mind if I did? I'd like to talk to him.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Sure.  Does your daughter want to come inside?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Uh, no, we're going to dinner... Is this the way to the pasture?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Pasture? Oh, that stretch of field near the hill? Yeah.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Mrs. MacLean -- why don't you and daughter stay for dinner?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh uh, thank you. No, we don't want to impose.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: No imposition. Plenty of food. Gonna get pretty dark soon. Hard to find a place.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: How's Peterson's holding up for you?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: It's fine. Comfortable. I still can't get used to how dark it gets around here, though. When we leave the ranch, I always hold my breath until I can see the motel.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Where does this go, Diane?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Oh, you can just set up on the dining table. I have to rearrange my shelves tomorrow.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Mm-mm. I never knew him. He died before Frank and I met. This here's...  Frank and Tom's mother and father... there's little Frank and Tom...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: She calls him Tommy...

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Always did. I think she favored him a little. You tend to when you have more than one, even though you love 'em all the same.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Ha, she loves telling this story about how when he was two years old, he ran off. They found him in the barn, sleeping between two giant hooves of a Percheron stallion. She said that horse was protecting him and nobody could convince her otherwise.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I got a little confused though. The ranch Ellen was talking about -- that's not this one?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Thank you. You're all doing too much.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Oh, it's... I wanted to tell you that, if you'd like, you being so busy, I could take Grace to her therapy exercises for you. I have to go in once a week for shopping anyway.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: I'll help you with the coffee.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well... I know I should reject that offer, but I'm not going to.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: No reason you should, no reason you should.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: I was looking in one of your magazines and saw that picture of the couple getting married at the Pyramids. Were you ever in Egypt?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I was there for that shot, actually.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: What was it like?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, God -- I think it was the fourth or fifth time I'd been there, so all I remember was the heat and how incompetent the photographer was...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: But, uh, Egypt is, well, it's like nothing else. It's like going back in time.  I remember as a kid trying to imagine what a kid my age, centuries ago, walking over that same ground, was wondering about or, if they had the same problems as me... and I felt, connected to... to time itself, almost. Ha, I never realized how hard it was to describe.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: I'd love to go there one time...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You and Frank ever take a vacation?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Soon. We're going to Branson, Missouri to see my cousin Emma married. Frank loves in there.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Must be nice for you to take a few days off from your work, huh?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well, I have more than a few days, ha, ha... I uh... I'm sort of... not an editor anymore... right now... First time I've said it out loud.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: They fired you?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: No, it's more like a leave of-  Ha, ha, ha. Yeah, they fired me.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: You don't seem to upset?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Delayed shock. Or maybe not. I know I could talk my way back if I wanted or... go to another magazine, someplace... Just not sure if I want to.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Guess you don't have to figure it out until you go home.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Did you always know this was the life you wanted?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: I fell in love. After that, I never thought about being anything but a rancher's wife. I never saw it like I was losing some other life, just felt like I was gaining one. I know that's not a popular opinion nowadays and I ain't saying it's the right one. We all have to find the life meant for us.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Frank's a good man.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: They don't come better. But I don't deny there are times I wonder about things I won't have. Maybe one day I'll get to see Egypt. Maybe not. But I know if you try too many different lives, you can wind up with no life at all...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Sounds like something Tom would say.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Yes, it does.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Annie, I'm not good at this kind of talk -- goes round and round a thing but never comes to it -- so let's just say what it is. When you first came here, I didn't like you and I was worried. Tom means a lot to me and this family. Don't go looking here for whatever you looking for. Don't make that man go through something it took him a long time to see his way clear out of the first time.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I don't think anybody can make Tom do anything he didn't want.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: He's a good man, Tom is. He's got a gift, come from heaven above, I swear. But he's still a man. And a woman can lead a man into the middle of a mountain lake -- and still make him think he's on dry land.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Is there anything you need? I'm going food-shopping.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Well, I am going to go after lunch.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: No, no, I'll go -- just give me a list.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: I think I'm going to have my hands full with the son of mine when you leave. Just might be his first broken heart.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, how sweet.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Now, are you sure you want to drive that horse back yourself? There are plenty of people 'round here who do that sort of thing.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I already know the way... and it's not like I have a job I have to rush home for.  Between you and me, I could use the time alone.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: It's just one night. If I get uncomfortable, I'll go over to Hanks.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Promise?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Promise.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Good luck to you, Annie.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You too, Diane.

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: Annie, it's Liz. How's Grace?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Her leg was shattered so they had to, uh... remove it. She had some bleeding but it's under control.

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: Oh God, Annie, I'm so sorry. I... I know you're being hit with a low now, I don't want to take too much of your time but I have to talk to you about Pilgrim.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Wait, uh, I, I don't understand. Start again -- He's alive...

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: Yes, but he's in a tremendous pain...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well, of course, right...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Liz, listen, the Doctor's here and I just can't, uh... talk now... so --

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: I understand, but Annie, please...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: - See, what you can do for him --...

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: Annie, no matter what I do, this horse will never be the same.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: ... I just don't know right now! Do whatever you can and when Grace is --

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: It isn't right to make him suffer...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: And I can say the same thing about my daughter! But she is suffering! Can you solve that problem!  I can't deal with this now, Liz! If you need a yes or no right now, then no -- don't do it! Not until I know Grace is all right. Now, please! Just do what you can. Okay?  Please.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Maybe we should give him another sedative.

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: Problem is, there aren't many volunteers. He's already had enough to sink a battleship. You have a pin, just in case?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Of course not.

turns.speaker: LIZ
turns.text: Probably best. You may want to shoot yourself half way to Ohio.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: ... well, I just think she's got a lot of nerve showing up here. Draggin' that child and that poor animal all the way...  You eat with those fingers again and you know what'll happen!  Frank, don't you think she's got a nerve?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Oh hell, I don't know... According to Tom, she's a pretty determined woman. Must've thought it was worth it.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: I guess they'll want feeding and all, out here all day long.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Mixed salad.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: I believe women from New York eat mixed salads. Ain't that right, Tom?

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: They're already all settled in, Frank. Anyway, I'm sure Annie wants her privacy.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: It's got doors, Diane. Private as can be. Tom?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Play that sweet one you know. The one makes my wife here so friendly.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: You!

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Oh Frank, don't forget the wedding present -- it's behind the door in the laundry room.  I got her a pasta maker from the catalogue... Not that they'll know what to do with it in Branton, Missouri... Probably use it as a planter.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Diane!

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Frank's touchy about his cousins.  Well, it was nice to meet you, Mr. MacLean.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I don't believe they'll expect that.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: What, they ain't going forty miles into Choteau everytime they want a hamburger.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I believe so. Saw it on a television show, once.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Well, that's just what we need on a cattle ranch -- a vegetarian from New York.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Ha...

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Diane takes care of the books. I don't know how, but at the end of every month, everything adds up to the penny.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: Ain't brain surgery.

turns.speaker: DIANE
turns.text: I have some brownies left over. Want one?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: No thanks.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Can we take a look at Bronty's foal when we're done here, Dad?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Sure. As long as she don't mind.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: There's a kid at school says we should've imprint-trained him.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: He says if you do it soon as they're born, it makes them real easy to handle later on.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: That's what some folks say.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: There was this thing on the TV about a guy who does it with geese. He has this airplane and these baby geese all grow up thinking it's their mom, and he flies it and they just follow.  You hear 'bout that, Uncle T?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: When you figure on branding?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Weekend after next...

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Teacher asked me why we raise Black Angus-Herefords 'stead of Pure Herefords.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Tell her they suit the weather better. Their udders are black, 'stead of pink.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Now son, you tell 'em when it came from.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Be honest, I can't say I did it all myself. My grandma helped me get the words right.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I don't believe it.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: You know her?

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Tom?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Bank out us a couple more men to run the cattle.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: We should be fine, then.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: They don't get burned by the sun bouncing off the snow. And they're good mother.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: Our daddy raised Pure Herefords.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Well, I'd like to welcome Annie and Grace to their first branding...

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: And next time, Miss Annie, you can run down the calves...

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: It'd be a whole lot easier to pay the feed end of the month...

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I don't think Warren would go for that.

turns.speaker: FRANK
turns.text: We thought we lost him in the snow storm... Told the kids. Had a funeral for the damn thing. Finally, snow stops. Staring to warm up. I go out and start cleaning the truck... Goddamn if that dog doesn't jump out from the back seat covered in snow... I nearly stained myself.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: He thought it was a ghost.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Don't you go to school?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Twice a month they give you a day off to work on the ranch.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Why do you always wear that hat?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Because it fits my head. You want to try it on?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Would you let me ride your horse?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Have you talked to Tom about it?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Of course I have.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I don't know... You sure Tom said it's all right?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: You wouldn't want to dance with me, would you?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: I don't thinks you'd want me tripping all over you in front of everybody.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I wouldn't let happen.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: You know, you're a good kid.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Uh, I'm Tom Booker. Your mother around?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: She gonna be long?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Probably. She's on the phone twenty- three hours a day.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: What does she do?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: She's an editor.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Mmm. An editor.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Not like books or literature or anything. Just a magazine... Just in case she hasn't told you -- which I'm sure she hasn't -- I don't want to be a part of this, OK?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Isn't it like, obvious?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Not to me. Either you want to or you don't.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: That's not a question, is it?

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: You're catching on.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Can you drive?

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: Drive? I'm not old enough yet.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: It's never too soon to start.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: I can't...

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: I don't have all day.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Put the key in and turn it.  The right pedal is gas, the other one's the brake.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: I don't know if I can with my leg.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Well, there's only one way to find out.  Give it a little gas.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Just follow this. Nothing to it. I'm going to shut my eyes here for a little while. Just keep going till you run out of road.

turns.speaker: GRACE
turns.text: I don't know if I can.

turns.speaker: TOM
turns.text: Not a question of if you can -- you are. Just keep your eyes on the road and your foot on the pedal and the rest will take care of yourself.
